backend.environment
Class Animal

java.lang.Object
  backend.environment.Element
      backend.environment.Animal
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable
Direct Known Subclasses:
Predator, Prey
public abstract class Animal
extends Element
implements java.lang.Cloneable

Animal is a subclass of Element and superclass to Prey and Predator. It enables us to group Prey and Predators together when we don't need to distinguish between the two. For all Animals, the radius is understood as the sight radius (ie. how far the animal can see). The calculateUpdate(...) method makes use of a number of behaviour weights that determine how the animal behaves at any given frame:

  1. collision avoidance - the tendency to avoid fellow flock-mates
  2. velocity matching - the tendency to move in the same direction as fellow flock-mates
  3. flock centering - the tendency to keep near other flock-mates
  4. waypoint attraction - the tendency to move towards target waypoints
  5. terrain avoidance - the tendency to move along smoother paths

See Also:

Method Detail

getVelocity

public Vec getVelocity()
Description copied from class: Element
Returns the velocity vector of the Element The velocity vector of an Element is a vector with size < 1. To get the final velocity (which is returned), this vector is scaled by the maximum speed

Specified by:
getVelocity in class Element
Returns:
The final velocity vector of the Element

setVelocity

public void setVelocity(Vec v)
Description copied from class: Element
Sets the velocity vector of the Element. If the vector is too big then it is truncated. The vector given is scaled down by the maximum speed of the Element.

Specified by:
setVelocity in class Element
Parameters:
v - The to-scale velocity vector of the Element

public void setTarget(Waypoint t)
Description copied from class: Element
Sets the target waypoint of the Element

Overrides:
setTarget in class Element
Parameters:
t - The new target of the Element

update

public void update()
Description copied from class: Element
Every Element needs to be updated every simulation loop cycle. In order for this to happen two things need to happen:
  1. The update for the next cycle needs to be calculated
  2. The update needs to be applied
This function does the second step

Overrides:
update in class Element
